column11: Just back from Sri Lanka, where I spent 2 nights in Arugam bay. Even though I knew it was not the peak season in the east of the country,I never expected it to be so quiet. I think it was a combination of being off season and Covid, that had the place looking like a ghost town.  There were very few restaurants and bars open while we were there and the streets were deserted after 8pm. It didnt help that there were power cuts also happening and lots of places had no electricity, which made it eerie walking home in the darkness. In saying all that, we stayed in the Spice trail which was a great choice and the people were very friendly. They also arranged a safari trip to Kumana park, which is only a 45 min journey away and we saw lots of animals, with very little other people around. The beach is a real working beach with lots of fishing boats along the shore constantly going in and out with their catches. So dont expect a beach with lovely stretches of sand with plenty of sun loungers. Its not that type of beach. I would certainly like to visit again when its peak season, to really see this place at its best and then make a better judgement.

column11: Just wrapped up eight days in Sri Lanka‚Äôs Arugam Bay - a rather rare part of the world in that it‚Äôs still relatively raw and untouched by commercialization and development. It truly is a surfer‚Äôs paradise, with a main point in Arugam Bay itself and various others within 15-20 minutes by Tuk Tuk. We spent most of our time at Whiskey Point as that was where the swell was best ‚Äî we visited in early June. The beach is also spacious at that point and offers a lot of room to throw a towel down and swim/surf. Not much else though so would not recommend to stay near there. Arugam Bay is definitely where it‚Äôs at as there are restaurants/cafes and a few bars. Some points to make: This destination is about surfing, yoga and chilling. There‚Äôs waves for all kinds of riders and many day trips on offer - safari, jungle, etc. It‚Äôs crucial to go during the right season though. I imagine most restaurants and places are closed otherwise, which would be a shame as you‚Äôd not get to explore this lovely place for what it is - a dream for many travelers! There‚Äôs not much of a beachfront; it‚Äôs filled with boats and so you probably won‚Äôt spend much time laying on the beach in A Bay. This didn‚Äôt bother us as we were busy surfing and then catching a break in the room mid day. But I can see some people putting up a fuss over this so figured it‚Äôs worth a mention. If you want to sunbathe a lot, stay somewhere with a pool. The mornings and evenings are lovey but it does get pretty hot & sweaty in the afternoon. Do yourself a favor and make sure you get a room with A/C. Nothing like being able to chill out in a cool room after a busy morning out on the beach or riding around. The area is predominantly Muslim so there are a lot of limitations on alcohol availability. You can‚Äôt get beer or hard alcohol at that many places - maybe 3 to 4 spots along the main strip. Only one bottle shop with actual hard liquor (down a road at the end of Arugam Bay where there is a holiday inn sign) and one with beer (Meena‚Äôs) to buy your own. I‚Äôd suggest packing a bottle if you wanna enjoy drinks in your room or whatever where you‚Äôre staying. Def places to grab cocktails though so no sweat if you just want a rum and coke here and there. This is something I wish I knew in advance - def would‚Äôve liked to have my own supply for my room and by the pool in the afternoon or evening! That being said, Arugam Bay is cheap and the cocktails will only cost you like $3-$5 at the bars that have them so you can drink to your heart‚Äôs desire even on a budget. Hideaway Resort‚Äôs Bar has great cocktails. Spice Trail bar has wine and bubbles (by the bottle) - both are next to each other. Last thing: we split our stay between two places .. Bay Vista, with a beach view and balcony .. and Spice Trail, which had a pool. This was such a good combo. We loved sitting on our balcony and enjoying the beach views for a few days. But it was equally enjoyable to go for a refreshing dip in the pool when we moved resorts. Both in the best location as well. All in all, we had an awesome trip with loads of surfing & lots of down time to chill and read. It‚Äôs a very mellow and chilled out place so definitely go expecting that kinda vibe. Happy surfing üèÑ Also, photo attached for transport service we used. Very comfortable and efficient for journey to Arugam from Colombo. Sanju is a great guy!

Beginner surfers are advised to take a 15 minute tuk-tuk ride from the main strip area to a spot called 'Whisky Point.' While we were told by some that this recommendation is also based on giving more business to tuk-tuk drivers, 'Whisky Point' is indeed quite a good spot for beginner surfers. Waves are still fairly strong, but not too dangerous; also, the area has a sand bottom as opposed to a rock bottom. Best to get there for around 7 a.m. as it could get crowded later in the day. The prices to rent surf boards and boogie boards are quite reasonable and you can probably negotiate prices if you feel like you're given an unreasonable price (especially if you're a foreign tourist). There's plenty of surf shops and prices of the one we went to (Hang Ten or something like that, with a guy named Raji) was quite good and the customer service was great. In the coast along the main strip area, if you just want to spend time in the shade, you can just purchase a beverage (overpriced!) from the multiple huts along the beach and hang out in the shade. The food: Your experience with the food scene depends on the places you go to. We went to a place called Water Edge a couple of times and the food and service was quite good. You could find cheaper places to eat, but the food at this place was quite tasty. Try the seafood platter which is about Rs.1500/= and is one of the more expensive items on the menu. Most restaurants also have vegetarian options; make sure to specify what kind of vegetarian you are, because some add egg to the food even if you say you're vegetarian.

column11: I was in Arugam -bay last week. Commencing from Kandy, taking the A4 motorway, -through 18hair pin bends up to Mahiyangana and from there, to Bibile-Monaragala-Siyambalanduwa- and through the Lahugala national park border, reached Pothuwil town. The entire journey from Kandy to Pothuwil took about 5 ¬Ω hours.  First, I went to Comari which was 14km away from Pothuwil town and 17km from Arugambay. On my way back to Arugambay I visited the ‚ÄúWhisky point‚Äù which is another surfing point within the bay. Arugam -bay is a quite a large bay, curved from the coast line of the Indian Ocean where the main tourist area as well as the key surf point is commonly called Arugam bay. This location is predominantly a fishing village where fishing boats are parked along the beach behind most of the hotels, inns and shallays alongside the beach side. It is this area along the arugmbay road, that you can find most of the hotels, inns, eating joints, road side restaurants and various activities which make the entire arugam  bay road alive when darkness falls. It is the off season for this beautiful bay. Why we call it the ‚Äúoff season‚Äù is because, from the beginning of this month the rolling waves most suitable for surfing start diminishing . The sea becomes calm where those people who love sun and sand and a dip in the sea, the environment is ideal. The hustle bustle in the tourist area will come to a low end but for those who likes a bit of a peaceful environment and not much interested in surfing its ideal. May be the small waves forming in the whisky point would be suitable for learners of surfing . The mornings are quite warm and the temperature goes over 30 degrees Celsius but the afternoon hours are cloudy and even you can experience slight rain. The sea is calm and ideal for a dip in the water for guys who love sun and sand. Most of the beaches in the bay are quite clean and nice. As the room rents during this season comes down drastically, guys who wish to have a quiet holiday at budget rates ,this season would be a good selection but not for surfing. Lets talk about Comari and Whiskey point. Comari is a quiet place where there are few lodging places for tourists. As it is only 14km from the Arugambay, one who hires motor bike or get a tuk tuk it would be cheaper to stay in Comari and vist Arugmbay on daily basis to have fun. If not, it is not difficult to find a place to lodge in Arugambay itself during this period as you get only few tourists and surfers there. For a person who is interested about other attractions, the famous bird sanctuary ‚ÄúKumana‚Äù national  park is only 28 km from Pothuwil town. If you hire a Safari jeep, it may cost you between 10 to 15 USD to proceed to ‚ÄúKumana‚Äù and come back to Arugambayin the evening.  The Lahugala national park is also in close proximity to Pothuwil town where it would be the same rate or less to travel in the morning and return in the evening. Ofcourse, I really enjoyed my stay in Comari and Arugam-bay during this off season which paved the  way for a budget stay for me.

column11: We spent a night at Arugam Bay in early April 2017.  This wide clean beach, with golden sand, is still unspoilt, virgin and utopian.  We strolled along the beach late in the evening and early morning watching the sunset and the sunrise from the eastern coast.  Photographs attached.  We could not swim though during this visit as the sea was still rough at this time of the year. The swim time at the beach is from about June until September/October when the sea is calm.  However, surfers as well as tourists come here in great numbers during that season from all over the world.  I am told that one has to book early to get reasonable accommodation. Arugam Bay is basically a fishing village.  The fishing boats that return in the morning with their catch was a sight I enjoyed and photographed. There are many small to medium hotels here with mid-range restaurants along the road running parallel to the beach and along the beachfront itself. Arugam-bay‚Äôs beauty was not accessible until the end of the war in 2009 as the area was under terrorist control.  After the end of the war both local and foreign tourists flock here to bask in the beauty of this beach. Since we were there only for one night we could not explore the surrounding areas.  It is my intention to return during the June ‚Äì September season for an extended stay with a few visits to the surrounding temples and the Kumana National Park only 10km from here.

column11: Arugam Bay is the well known beach for surfing in Sri Lanka. Only thing is you must select the correct season to visit if you are really interested in Surfing. Although, throughout the year you have reasonably enough waves here, during the season you will find everything perfect including the weather conditions for Surfing. Early months and Last Two months of the each year are normally considered as off-season but accommodations and foods become very cheap during these months. You can find a small beach front room (without A/C) for about Rs. 1,000. If you are not a budget traveler, don't worry, you have well established hotels with star ratings offering 50%-60% discounts during this period. Rain will be the main enemy of any traveler during this period and normally they expects thunderstorms every evening specially in April. The beach also becomes bit unclear due to the rain in off season. Beach may become fairly crowded during weekends, with locals specially in April as it is a school vacation month in Sri Lanka. After July or in some years late June, foreigners start filling the rooms and restaurants in all the corners of this area. When it becomes the winter season to Australia/New Zeelands, quite a lot of Ausis can be found in the streets. The busiest period really starts by August, which is considered as the best time to Surf. You will get the best waves for Surfing during this period and it will last until mid or may be end of October. If you were lucky enough to be there during these months, you can find plenty of Surfers in the beach and if you are new to Surfing, don't worry, you can catch a trainer with all equipment at a reasonable prices. I was told that one hour session would cost only Rs. 2,000 including a trainer and Surfing Board. Almost all the restaurants and hotels have international menu and Thai, Italian and Chinese foods are well famous in this area. You can have a very small taste of local foods and culture in this area specially during the peak season. Anyway, trust me you will not have to be in hungry, as you have a wide range of foods available from Pizza to Fried Rice. Arugam Bay is about 200 km away from Capital and if you are a backpacker you have enough transport options. If you have all your Surfing Boards and other big bags, you will have to hire a vehicle which may be bit expensive. Ampara is the nearest main city but you can find several small town thereafter like Akkaraipattu and Pothuwil. From Colombo there is a bus going to Arugam Bay every night sharp at 9.00 pm. It will reach Its destination by next morning and stop one time for tea. This is a a luxury bus with AC and you will be charged Rs. 1,200 one way. On your way back also bus will leave Arugam Bay by 9.00 pm and reach to Colombo by next morning. After visiting many of the beaches in Sri Lanka, I cannot say that Arugam Bay is the best beach in Sri Lanka but it can be considered as the best destination for Surfers. If you have enough time don't miss this attraction, go there and fill another seat in a crowded restaurant.

column11: Arugam Bay is a bay situated on the Indian Ocean in the dry zone of Sri Lanka's southeast coast. The bay is located 320 kilo meters due east of Colombo, and approximately 4 kilo meters south of the market town of Pottuvil. The Arugam Bay area is home to a number of quality surf breaks, the most popular of which being 'Main Point' located towards the south of the bay. This is a right hand point break, with a rock/reef bottom, and has a number of sections with occasional barrels. Other breaks in the area include Whiskey Point and Pottuvil Point to the north, and Elephant Rock, Peanut Farm and Okanda to the south. These breaks have attracted a steady stream of international tourists for several decades. Arugam Bay has a good local surf scene and is home to some of Sri Lanka's most talented surfers. In recent years surfers from Arugam Bay have dominated national competitions.

column11: Surfers Select Arugam bay for a Perfect Surfing Holiday for it's Free Atmosphere for Surfer Life Style, as the best Surfing Destination for Beginners for it's varying size of Surfing waves. Arugam Bay is one of the TOP 10 surf points in the world. It is also a sandy beach of stunning natural beauty. Arugam Bay's proximity to Lahugala National Park & Yala East National Park makes it a unique surfing beach. The bay lies between two headlands & is excellent for surfing. Arguam bay is located 320 km from Colombo. Some 60km due east from Monaragala, Arugam Bay is a tiny fishing village 3km south of the small fishing village of Pottuvil which is at the remote southern end of the Eastern coast & on the edge of Yala East National Park. The wide, sweeping sandy beach in front of the fishing village is an attraction for swimming all year-round. The beach is usually deserted, except at the southwest corner. In the South west corner, fishing boats & thatch huts indicates the  tiny fishing village of Ulla, just to the south of the guest house area. Also this is also the safest area for swimming with a water temperature of 24-28 centigrade year-round, where you don't need a wet suit to swim or surf in this waters. As far as the techniques of surfing is concerned, 'The Point' in Arugam Bay is regarded as one of the  top world surf destinations. It is a well lined up right hand point break, generating a clean peeling glassy wave that barrels a surfer, a 400 meter ride right through to the inside of the wave. Additionally there are four or five high quality breaks within a radius of 30 minutes. Pottuvil point in the northern end of Arugambay is often deserted. However this area is  popular with more experienced surfers.  Crocodile Rock , 3kms south of Arugam Bay is a long, deserted beach from where wild elephants can quite often be seen. Pottuvil lagoon is a haven for numerous bird species. Arugam Bay's picturesque lagoon divides Ulla village from Pottuvil lagoon, north of town. The bridge is an excellent vantage point to see the sunset, & at night you can watch prawn fishermen throwing, gathering & emptying their nets.

column11: The first time I visited Arugam Bay was back in 1994, when the Sri Lankan civil war  was at full tilt, and visits to the East coast were by the foolhardy or do or die surfers from Australia. it was just before christmas that year, when about 7 of us, in two vehicles, left Colombo early one cool December morning, and took the road to first Ratnapura, and then turned Eastwards on the Embilipitiya road to Arugam Bay. It took much of the day to reach there, as the roads were B roads, badly maintained, full of snaking twists and turns.The saving grace was the breathtaking scenery: we passed waterfalls, rice paddies, and sleepy vilages and towns until we reached Moneragala, the nearest large town to Pottuvil and the Bay. We had a late lunch at the Rest House there. From here on, it was the war zone, The road was deserted, except for the odd bus and trucks carrying produce. Checkpoints, manned by army mostly , dotted the road.We had to stop and show our IDs inumerable times. From Siyabalanduwa onwards the checkpoints were manned by the Special Task Force, STF, the paramilitary special ops force that policed the East Coast.Tension was in the air. The checkpoint personnel were monosyllabic, surly at times, with red-rimmed eyes, pointing to sleepless nights and a lot of stress.Although the LTTE had not mounted a big operation in the East coast that year, there were small incursions al the time. I drunk it all in-the tension went hand in hand with the dark green foliage of the dense forests on either side of this road. If we got blown up on this road, it was all worth it-died on the road to Arugam Bay, chasing a wave, what an epitah, I thought. When we passed Siyambaladuwa, the vegetation began to change.It was no longer wet zone tropical but dry zone, with its spiky foliage, a more yellowish colour, smaller leaves, and sparser.And the heat began to ratchet up.There were landscapes of green rice paddy fields stretching to the horizon on both sides of the road now. Occasionally there were small tractors trundling on the road. More checkpoints. Then we reached Lahugala Forest Reserve, which was by the road, from which one was supposed to see Elephant herds snacking on the lush grass of the tank bed there. We stopped, and there were a couple of Grey Ghosts there. Their trunks swayed as they tore up the grass.It was our first sight of the magic of the jungles here, and well worth the 8-hour drive. It was getting towards dusk, and we had get off this road before the light went. The road now was really bad, pot holed and very small, untouched since the 1950s , it seemed. On both sides were dry paddies and salterns, streching to the horizons. The road didnt allow for a speed in excess of 10 mph:it seemed quicker to walk, but we would probably get shot by the STF, who were probably patrolling out somewhere out there. The final checkpoint was reached, when we got to Pottuvil, the dusty, one road, one horse - million tractor little town which would be immortalised in our minds as Potters. We stopped for a while in Potters, drinking in the sights while slaking our tea habit in a tea boutique. A town of bycycles and tractors, and rusty, beaten up up vans and STF soldiers carrying T-56 automatics. We had stocked up with fresh veggies and food in Moneragala, as wher we were headed to had a cook.There was only one hotel/guest house  in the Bay, the Stardust hich was owned by a Danish couple who had been here ages.But they charged major bucks for rooms.I and two friends, a couple, were going to stay in the run down guest house owned by a family friend. The others, another couple an their teenage son would stay in the Stardust. There was a glorious sunset dying as we crossed the bridge into the Bay.The winds blowing from the sea promised something, maybe crab curries and grilled prawns. The Stardust was immediately identifiable, set back on the left in its neat sandy grounds, a sold white building, with some small cabanas out facing the sea. We were in the Hideaway, a ramshackle old building, hidden away in a mass of Bourganvillea and some scattered coconut trees. It was run by a very dodgy caretaker, who met us smoking a cheroot, dressed in a sarong, and very suspicious of these dusty, sweaty oiks from Colombo, with a white girl in tow. After some preliminary sparring, he agreed to let us stay in the rooms upstairs.There were cabanas, but they were falling down, rat and mosquito infested, he said. The owner of the Hideaway was involved in a court case trying to get rid of the caretaker, who had a reputation of using the place for prostitution and drugs. Arugam bay always had great rep for the best grass in Sri Lanka: I wanted to do some inhaling while I was there, i was all part of the package. Problem-there was no cook:we would have to do our own dinner. Of all of us, I had the most experience of cooking, my friends were in the fry-ups, toast and cereal brigade.I got them slicing and dicing, and we had brought some chicken, which I managed to get into a semblance of a curry. The other layabouts did a salad, and we tucked in after a shower in our rickety rooms, which had  fans and mossie nets. No crabs and prawns tonight, but we were too tired to care, and after dinner we headed of to the Stardust down the road, the night starlit and still. After several ice cold beers,and lots of chat , making plans for the days ahead we called it and staggered back, nearly dissappearing into some of the potholes on the road. I collapsed on my bed, arranging the mossie net as well as I could and left for noddieland. I was woken up suddenly by what seemed to be the apocalypse breaking over the bay.It was World War Three:the bulding was shaking, there were flares lighting up the outside, and I could see tracer fire acing into the night,The noise was horrendous.Convinced I was going to die imminently, I ran next door to where my friends were, and leaped into their room. They were under the bed. I joined them. "What the hell is going on?", my pal's English girlfriend yelled, as another mortar seemed to alight in the garden, shaking the paper thin walls. "I think the Tigers are coming, J-, and I want you to surrender to them, seeing you are a tourist you'll;;be okay and as we are together they wont kill us" said my pal ,her boyfriend.Always thinking ahead my buddy R-. I really wished I had eaten a crab curry and got hold of some Bay weed tonight:atl east I would have gone out with great memories. I thought of my mum back in Colombo, an all the things I hadnt done yet, the women I hadnt dated yet, the music I hadnt heard, the cars, I hadnt driven, the countries I hadnt been to,a long long Bucket list. Then, as suddenly as it had begun, the fireworks stopped. We crawled out, shaken and well stirred, and looked out at he darkness.The Hideaway had no power anyway, so  it was dark everywhere.No sign of life, no signs of Tigers walking up the path, nothing. The stillness of the night returned, and even the cicadas began to chirp cautiously.It was around 3 am. We opened some scotch to celebrate being alive, and went back to bed. The next morning, we asked the first SF guy we saw what had happened. He laughed, albeit rather hysterically, I thought. "Oh, that?Nothing to worry about, we were just getting rid of our old ammo stocks before the New year" he said walking away quickly. Dumbfounded, we looked at each other and chalked it up to more of inimitable Sri Lankan humour. The next few days were idyllic:we pickniked in a green dale beyond which we saw a hoard of copulating turtles, their shells glistening in the sun, saw ancient temples on beaches,saw Elephants and Buffalos together on th roadside, and visited Kudumbigala rock monastery, where the silence of millennia ruled the heights and meditation caves, the haunt of Bear and Leopard. We body surfed in some forgotten cove where the fish nibbled at our toes , and visited deserted, empty beaches running for miles., visited the hushed grandeur of Radella tank, where forest giants stalked the bund. I got my crab curry but no hash, which I got on another trip. Over it all lay the feeling of a frontier, a place forgotten by time and the hordes  of the  20th century. I have been to Arugam bay many times since then,  caught the surf one full moon night,but the world has changed:Gone are the checkpoints, the palpable taste of danger and tension in the air,Gone too are most of the Elephants. But Kudumbigala monastery remains the same, human history nothing but a blip in its millennial count, its caves a silent reminder of eternity. The Hideaway is now a thriving resort, famous for its food, and the Stardust is still there,, although the Danish Manager was swept away in the  grea Tsunami of 2003. There are a host of small hotels and guesthouses, and the surfing is now on global to-do lists by all surfers.The jungles are still there, now dwindling sadly.The 21st century has come to the Bay. But the feeling of a frontier is still there,although our experience was quite special.Perhaps you have to be Sri Lankan to realise we saw a frontier just before it began to change. When what we got couldnt be charged to a credit card or to a wad of dollars. To paraphrase  the Roman Pliny we "watched the cold star Saturn, and saw honey come out of the air at the rising of the Dog-star just before the dawn." Tread softly the dust of Arugam Bay, it carries memories.

The weather looked ok so we paid a visit. The sea and beach were both unpleasant, just a bit dirty to be honest, and as it was out of season most places were shut so it seemed like a ghost town. It felt like there was some sort of unrest going on. It gave us an uneasy feeling. As I say if you're planning to visit check it's in season and try to gather info from a like minded traveller or T.Ad. Before making the long journey as we did. We only stayed a night and traveled 14hrs over two days to be hugely disappointed. Also the Lonely Planet warns against travel to this area for single women. We were traveling as a couple (male and female) and my girlfriend felt really uncomfortable. This area seems to be a Muslim area and without generalising about all Muslim men my girlfriend felt she was being stared at a great deal. And she was dressed conservatively not like a a teenager with a thong bikini! We have travelled many places so this opinion is based on other experiances we have had over years with some strong Muslim connections. Maybe this problem was what the Lonely Plant were touching on but were being politically correct so didn't spell it out. This experiance wasn't totally in your face but it was there all the same. It's the most uncomfortable place we've been to in Sri Lanka and was very unlike the usual local/tourist relationships. This is how we saw it anyway. I'm sure others would see things differently. Carefully consider your visit here. I wish I had.

column11: Probably one of the best spots in the world for beginner surfers, although its claim to being one of the top 5/10 overall point breaks will be questioned by those with Aus/Indo/South Africa/Hawaii experience. Having said that, when it's on at the point there are long and rewarding rides to be had for the pros. Think Noosa, but without the rocks. Waves lack the punch of the aforementioned countries so longboarders will find toes-on-the-nose nirvana. Switch-foot, dead cockroach, soul arches...you'll pull out your full back catalogue. ¬†Don't stress about bringing a board as new Thai-made mals are arriving by the day and can be rented cheaply. Because the waves get progressively smaller as they grind along the sand point it is brilliant for those learning or mid-range riders who what to cruise between Lion beers. If you persist, you will stand up here. It gets crowded but the break seems to handle it. There are other surf options a tuktuk ride away.¬†It's in the dry zone of Sri Lanka, so those expecting jungle, monkeys and palm trees will be disappointed. Try the west coast in the opposing surf season. Beer on tap at the Siam View Hotel.

column11: Spent 6 nights at Arugam Bay in July. Great beach for surfing with a giant sand bar separating the surfing beach and mainland, giving a great swimming area for children inbetween. This is great for families who want to surf but need someone for younger children to swim. The surfing waves did get busy late afternoon but it was quiet early in the morning. It is easy to rent surf boards or body boards (around rps 500 for 24 hours) and tuk tuk are a plenty to visit some of the other places to surf. On the negative side we had a bad experience with groups of young men fighting (very violently!) on the beach near the point one afternoon. It went on for quite awhile, and people with young children were unable to leave the beach without passing through what was happening (we were able to swim away with our children across the lagoon). Eventually, the army (who have a permanent presence on this beach) called for reinforcements and things calmed down, leaving shocked (and crying foreigners) on the beach. We thought it was all over but the next morning at 8am two groups of young men were arguing again but it resolved itself quickly. Locals we spoke to played the whole incident down saying it was just the youngsters getting out of hand and it was nothing but it was a frightening experience for us and we did wonder if this was why the army and tourist police are permanently based on the beach. Maybe this was a one off and we were unlucky to be there as we had seen no other trouble for the 5 days we had been there before, but were glad to leave the tensions behind when we moved on.

column11: Arugam Bay is one of worlds to ten surfing points. Therefor so many surfing loved tourists visit Arugam Bay in every season. The main season for Augam Bay is from May to November when the predominant wind is offshore for at least the first half of the day. Arugam Bay is situated about 350 Km away to the east coast of Sri Lanka from the Katunayeka Bandaranayeka International Airport. There are two three different ways to travel there. One easy road is from Airport to Colombo and then to Rathnapura. From Rathanapura to Kolabageara and through Udawalawa Dam to Thanamalwilla then turn towards Wallawaya after Turn towards Monaragala and then Siyabalanduwa now proceeds to Potuwill. The other road is through Rathnapura and Ella, Wallawaya to Manaragala. This is very scenic road and there are lots of eye catching views to stop. Also the  other remaining ways are From airport to Awissawella, Hatton, Nuwara Eliya through to Monaragala and then Arugam Bay. This road also has lot of breath taking views to see but rather mountainous road so it is harder to drive. If you are travelling in night leave the 2nd and 3rd ways use the 1st road. It is much safer and confortable.

column11: Arugam bay was a real highlight for us on a 6 week trip around sri lanka. SL seems to be a bit rip-off these days, compared with our last trip here in 2004, with silly prices for food and accommodation, especially in the south, south-east and near the "safari" zones.  But Arugam bay restored our faith. It's one of the last refuges of backpackers in the country (along with crazy hikkaduwa) and we had a real relaxing time here mixed with some exciting cycling journeys along the coast towards Panama village. We stayed at Beach Hut, always busy even out of season, we learned. Cheap rooms and genuinely great food. The main beach area is not the tropical beauty of, say, Thailand or malaysia, but that's more or less the case for all of sri lanka where the waves are generally enormous (ok if you're a surfer) and the beaches steep, not to mention strewn with plastic rubbish. Arugam beach was also a fishing beach which, apart from the inevitable scattered rubbish, made it all the more interesting. Nearby trips can be made to Pottuvil town and, further north, Pottuvil point, a popular surfer hangout in season but almost completely empty when we visited. Be careful swimming here due to currents from the lagoon (even if it looks very picturesque). Also Panama village, south of arugam, is possible by bicycle or tuktuk where the journey itself is great, rather than the village which is ok for some food and drinks. An English guy has bought up the land encompassing the point so the current peace may or may not change in future. at the moment there is only a restaurant and a few basic huts at the point itself but I guess this is a busy place in surfing season. The caretaker, sidike, is a wealth of local info and good company for a chat. it's a lonely job he has! Food is available from the guest houses or restaurants along the main road running behind the beach. We ate in the Beach Hut most nights as it was reasonably priced and very good Indian food.

column11: Hideaway is an absolutely gorgeous place and I believe the best accommodation and restaurant there is in Arugam Bay. Of my four-week round travel in Sri Lanka with my two young children, this place - it's beautiful aesthetics, loving attention to detail, superior food and incredibly kind and helpful owner Sharon and her staff; all culminating in creating the most enjoyable and relaxed, tranquil and peaceful atmosphere - stayed with us and would most certainly be the one to come back to. The bed and breakfast centers around the owner's old family holiday home, set back from the beach across the main road. The property consists of the main house and 6 or 7 bungalow-style units amidst a luscious, palm-tree adorned and color-kissed garden. The downstairs veranda style set-up of the main house functions as the reception, restaurant and open-air living-room - complete with old cupboards full of books, big rattan chairs and stone benches atopped with bright-colored cushions inviting you time and again to sink in and relax - all in one. Upstairs, enjoying a wide and beautiful balcony are a few rooms for rent. The bungalows come in various sizes. We stayed in one of the newer ones, which was a spacious (humongous bed and bathroom), minimalistic, clean - simply gorgeous unit. Arugam Bay is a small village on Sri Lanka's south-eastern coast, which has become a (family)-surfer's heaven. The main street is lined with one bed&breakfast  - some bigger hotels starting to sprout about, which hopefully will not do too much harm to the very chilled and relaxed, not yet too overcrowded feel of Arugam Bay - cafe, imbiss, restaurant, bar, surfer-boutique and corner-shop next to the other, which makes for perfect beach-holiday strolling and hanging-out: picking up your breakfast before descending on to the gorgeous main beach, which has a few great (mid-)day hang-out spots; sorting yourself with any snacks or beach-wear utensils anytime; enjoying one brilliant dinner after the other during your stay - unless of course Hideaway just keeps tempting you back in - probably the most stressful decision-making aspect during our stay!!! It's really a hideaway place - very big and green garden, a cozy and laid-back style lounge at the reception. All very atmaspheric. First night we stayed in one of the non-AC rooms (Rs 4k; dbl) above the reception. The room is simple and comfortable, but a lot of mosquitos - everytime I checked there were 10-15 on the mosquito net (outside). another drawback of these rooms are the top of walls are not "sealed", so you can easily hear other people's talking in the next room, or the music from downstairs, or the early morning mosque loud speakers. The corridor outside these rooms have very comfortable couch and cusions, love this part very much. The next night we opted for AC rooms (Rs 7k; dbl) on the 2nd floor of the little house closer to the road. There was very little traffic in Arugam Bay, so it wasn't a problem at all, and no loud speaker could be heard from here. The room was sytlishly decorated and was very very comfortable (and romantic). The A4 road going down to Arugam Bay has just finished upgrading to a nice road in August, so I'm pretty sure Arugam Bay will be back to the tourist map with huge popularity for Sri Lankans and foreigners alike. Go there before it gets exploited!

column11: Aragum Bay is a rustic fishing village with a world class wave.  Simple beach hotels (some don't provide toilet paper) and restaurants line the length of the beach.  The town is split down the middle between Muslim and Rastafarian so it is an interesting mix that seems to work just fine. I recommend Danish Villa.  It is a bit more expensive than other hotels ($42 night for my room) but it is spotlessly clean, has AC, and the staff is very helpful. The Thai restaurant in town is great and so was the Green Room for Sri Lankan curries. Take a tuk-tuk out of town to surf some less crowded waves or get up very early.  The main peak can be a mob scene at most times.  It is a great wave though.  Bring your own board if possible.  The rental scene is not nearly as good as other surf destinations.

column11: We stopped in Arugam bay as part of a round the island road-trip with plans for a three night stay. We left after one. Our choice was the Galaxy Hotel which did beach bum chic better than most, basically a big tree house with a large main room and stirs through a trap door to the bathroom. All good fun if the stairs hadn't been fitted wrong with all of the treads sloping downwards at at angle beyond exciting, particularly with a pregnant wife. No real complaints but a bit more effort in preparing the room room, at least emptying the ashtrays would have been welcome. What we really didn't like was the beach. It is a working fishing beach which sounds quite cool but the reality is working beaches are not clean and fishermen are not wealthy so there is never any sensation of being in a desert island paradise, in fact it was all a little bit squalid. What does make it worth a visit though is the journey, particularly from AB into the hills, this made the stop over worth the trip rather than, as is often the case in Sri Lanka, the other way around. I know it is surfer hippie cool but there are really much better places to stay and see in Sri Lanka

column11: We went to Arugam Bay on East Coast in July when told seas too rough on west coast due to monsoons. A real adventure getting there - last 10-12 miles to coast had road blocks about every mile, we hadn't realised how far down there the war troubles had spread, and this was only a few weeks after the peace was declared so they were still very nervous about trouble. But Arugam Bay was wonderful - hardly any tourists there at all, had fabuloous beach practically to ourselves. Everyone very welcoming, so badly need tourist business revived. It had been badly hit by the tsunami but most buildings along coastline had been rebuilt. No fancy hotels there yet - we stayed at beachfront place in photo which unfortunately can't find name of  - very basic but fine.
